chapters.name: Introduction
chapters.summary:
Core Idea: Computers use math to build, color, and move pictures of 3D things so they look real on screens in games, movies, and tools.

Key Concepts / Formulas:

  • Modeling: Describe any object with points, curves, and surface rules. Example: store a car as thousands of connected points and how shiny its paint is.
  • Rendering: Turn points into a colored picture with light and shadows. Example: make a 3D apple look red, round, and glossy.
  • Animation: Change the model over time and render many pictures quickly. Example: make a character wave or run smoothly at 60 pictures per second.
  • Graphics API: Toolkits like OpenGL or Direct3D that let your code draw fast on any computer or phone.
  • Graphics Pipeline: Fast factory inside the graphics card that takes triangles, moves them to screen position, shades them, and hides what is behind. Example: every game on your phone uses this to draw millions of triangles per second.

Visual / Practical Example: A video game character: points define the body (modeling), light and texture make skin and clothes look real (rendering), changing the arm positions 60 times a second makes it wave (animation), all drawn instantly by the graphics pipeline using OpenGL.

Connections: Everything in games, movies, VR, medical scans, and design software starts here: modeling creates the objects, rendering makes them visible, animation makes them move, and the pipeline + API make it run fast on real hardware.

One-Sentence Summary: Computer graphics turns math descriptions of 3D objects into fast, beautiful, moving pictures using modeling, rendering, animation, and the graphics pipeline.
